Federal Court
Phelan, J.
October 6, 2004.
Counsel:
Inna Kogan, for the applicant;
Counsel for the respondent is not disclosed.
Solicitors of Record:
Inna Kogan, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[3]
The remedy under Rule 399 is an extraordinary one to deal with inadvertent errors and to ensure consistency between the reasons for an order and the order itself. It is not a disguised method of appealing a decision; a particularly inappropriate step in immigration cases where there is no automatic right of appeal.
Evidence not before the Court

[4]
The Minister complains that the Court took into consideration the fact that Russia was prepared to accept Ms. Lazareva. Since the Minister had concluded that Bulgaria was the country to which she would return, despite her absence of Bulgarian citizenship, the country of return for purposes of her permanent residence application was an important fact.

[5]
During the course of the Minister's argument on the issue of "stateless person", counsel for the Minister relied on the fact that Russia would be able to admit her. This was information raised by Ms. Lazareva's counsel to which the Minister's counsel did not maintain an objection.

[6]
As a result the Court concluded that this fact was not in dispute. As a fact, it goes to a central issue in this judicial review. The Court can take into consideration facts arising after the decision being reviewed where they are particularly relevant. To conclude otherwise would be to force the Court to blindly ignore the true state of affairs.

[7]
The Court is now advised that the Minister does not accept this fact. If the place of return had been the only basis for overturning the Minister's decision, a reconsideration of the decision might be warranted. However, there were other reasons justifying overturning the Minister's decision which stand on their own. Therefore reconsideration is not warranted.
Granting H & C Application

[8]
The Minister says that the Court has no jurisdiction to grant Ms. Lazareva's H & C application. Even if that is what the Court had done, it would not constitute proper grounds for a Rule 397 motion.

[9]
The Minister concedes at paragraph 6 of its Written Representation in Reply that the Court has the jurisdiction to "direct the lower tribunal to come to a particular conclusion or issue directions such that it directs the result the tribunal must make". The Court's direction contained in the Order does precisely that. The Minister's discretion under section 25(1) of IRPA is to be exercised in a manner which gives effect to the Court's Order. The Minister has the jurisdiction to process Ms. Lazareva's landing application and the Court expects the Minister to do so.
Stay of Removal

[10]
Again, the grounds raised by the Minister do not constitute a proper basis for a Rule 397 motion. The Court's Order conforms to its reasons; the Minister is simply attempting a collateral attack or disguised appeal.

[11]
The jurisdiction of the Court under subsection 18.1(3) must be read in the context of section 18.1 as a whole, together with section 18 and the changes made to the Federal Court's jurisdiction.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.).

[12]
The Court has the power to issue directions which ensure that the purposes of its Order are not frustrated. An effort to remove Ms. Lazareva on the grounds that she is required to seek permanent residence from outside Canada would frustrate the Court's determination.

[13]
Rather than issue a direction to the Minister to make his necessary determination on Ms. Lazareva's application within specified time frames, the Court ensured that its principal decision would not be frustrated. It was and is expected that the Minister will get on with the task of dealing with Ms. Lazareva's application.
Conclusion

[15]
There are no good reasons to reconsider the Court's conclusion that no question will be certified.

[16]
If the Respondent has any issues in carrying out the Court's Order, it should seek further directions from the Court.
[End of document]

legal_issues: The permissible scope of reconsideration motions regarding judicial decisions.
Whether a court can consider evidence presented during argument that was not formally submitted.
The extent of judicial authority to direct administrative bodies to reach specific conclusions.
The appropriateness of a stay of enforcement actions pending resolution of a related application.
The jurisdictional limits of a court in reviewing administrative decisions regarding immigration status.
The relationship between a court's reasons for a decision and the order itself, and whether inconsistencies warrant reconsideration.
The power of a court to issue directions ensuring the effectiveness of its orders.
factual_background: Ms. Lazareva requested an exemption from the requirement to file an application for permanent residence from outside of Canada.
The Minister of Immigration denied Ms. Lazareva’s request for exemption on July 8, 2003.
Ms. Lazareva sought judicial review of the Minister’s decision.
The Court initially ordered the Minister’s decision quashed, directed the Minister to assess Ms. Lazareva’s application from within Canada, and stayed any removal proceedings.
The Minister argued that Russia was prepared to accept Ms. Lazareva, a fact initially presented during proceedings without objection.
The Minister subsequently disputed the assertion that Russia would accept Ms. Lazareva.
The Minister sought reconsideration of the Court’s order, alleging errors in the Court’s consideration of evidence and its decision regarding Ms. Lazareva’s application.
The Minister maintained the position that Bulgaria was the country to which Ms. Lazareva would return, despite her lack of Bulgarian citizenship.

Applicants: The Court mistakenly took into consideration evidence (Russia's willingness to accept Ms. Lazareva) that was not formally before it.
The Court mistakenly granted Ms. Lazareva's H & C application (though conceded the court has jurisdiction to direct a particular conclusion).
The Court mistakenly prohibited or restricted the Minister from attempting to remove Ms. Lazareva from Canada.
Respondents: The Minister's decision denying Ms. Lazareva's exemption request was valid and should not have been quashed.
The country of return (Russia) was a relevant fact, and the Court erred in considering it as undisputed when the Minister did not accept it.
The Court's order directing the Minister to assess the application from within Canada improperly restricted the Minister's discretion under section 25(1) of IRPA.
The stay of removal frustrated the Minister's ability to enforce the requirement that Ms. Lazareva apply for permanent residence from outside Canada.

court_analysis: The court found the Minister’s application for reconsideration under Rule 397 to be without merit, stating it is not a disguised appeal. The rule is reserved for inadvertent errors, not disagreement with the original decision.

Regarding the claim that the court improperly considered evidence (Russia’s willingness to accept Ms. Lazareva), the court acknowledged the evidence was introduced by the Minister’s counsel without objection during the initial hearing and thus was considered a fact not in dispute at that time. While the Minister now disputes this fact, the court reasoned that the original decision was justified by other grounds and therefore reconsideration was unnecessary.

The court affirmed its jurisdiction to direct the Minister to reach a specific conclusion regarding the application, citing the Minister’s own concession that the court can direct the lower tribunal to achieve a particular result. The court clarified that its order directing the Minister to assess the application from within Canada was a valid exercise of this jurisdiction, and the Minister’s discretion under IRPA section 25(1) must align with the court’s order.

The court rejected the Minister’s challenge to the stay of removal, finding it was a necessary measure to prevent the frustration of the court’s primary order. The court explained that its power under subsection 18.1(3) allows it to issue directions ensuring its orders are not undermined, and attempting removal while the application is under review would directly contradict the court’s determination.

The court emphasized its expectation that the Minister will promptly process Ms. Lazareva’s application and suggested seeking further directions if any issues arise in complying with the order, rather than attempting reconsideration.
final_outcome: The application for reconsideration was dismissed.
The respondent was directed to seek further directions from the Court if issues arise in carrying out the Court's Order.
